# Toll in Europe From '23 Heat: 47,000 Deaths

Steps to Adapt Sowed Thousands of Lives

**By AUSTYN GAFNEY**

More than 47,000 Europeans died from heat-related causes in 2023, the worst heat in more than a year, as new reports in Nature Medicine have found.

But the number could have been much higher.

Without heat adaptation measures over the past two decades, rising the same temperatures increasing the same temperatures in the start of the 21st century could have been 88 percent higher, according to the new study. For people over 60 years old, the toll could have doubled.

Some of the measures include measures in health care, more widespread anti-coagulation and more public healthcare measures like people indoor and hydrated during extreme temperatures.

“We need to consider climate change as a health issue,” said Elisa Giald, the lead author of the study, and a postdoctoral researcher at the Barcelona Institute for Global Health, a nonprofit research center. “We still have health costs of deaths and work lost every year, and we still have to be cautious. And we have to work with the public.”

Couting deaths from extreme heat is difficult, a part because death certification and early surveillance could help avoid public mortality, said the lead author. The study reached 70 countries, including 28 that did not. The study provided valuable information, including 25 countries, protecting 48,000 lives, including 15,000 from heat-related deaths.

The researchers used an epidemiological model to analyze the deaths’ associated 2023 weekly heat records of deaths outside a country’s borders.

“We’re quickly approaching the limit of what we can do,” said the study’s lead author, Carlos A. Velez, a professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, who was not involved in the study, as the latest confirmed case in the study was a “new case” against the clock.

“We’re not going to be able to mitigate the heat,” said Carlos A. Velez, a professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, whose work was not involved in the study, as the latest confirmed case in the study was a “new” case against the clock.
